Post_Title: There is absolutely no reason why an all powerful, all knowing, self sufficient God would create humans and demand their worship.
post_text:
This is one of those questions that if you dive deep enough into your end up with responses such as "We don't understand God's wisdom" 

But this is a cop out. 

God has no need to create people solely for them to worship him when he is self sufficient and all ppwerful. He gains nothing from the worship of his own creation. It makes zero sense for God to demand worship.

Anyways, my challenge is: 

There is no good reason why a God would require worship when it does not affect him in any way shape or form. 

God gains nothing from our worship. He also gains nothing from putting us in heaven or hell. 

It is all very arbitrary and makes no sense from a Gods perspective. 

It makes sense if you consider that maybe a human made this all up.

Threads.Reply_Text: The life of a God, if one existed, would be so different than ours that it makes no sense to try and understand their reason for doing things. Do you think an ant can understand your motivations?

Replies.Reply_Text: Right, so we have no way to properly predict such a God's motivations. Meaning that religions that try to explain their God's motivations are taking a wild shot in the dark, and are almost certainly wrong.

We couldn't ever establish it for certain. At the end of the day it all comes down to whether you're personally convinced. But just because you personally don't see any convincing reason or evidence for something, doesn't mean there objectively isn't any. It just means you're personally not convinced. That's fine, but just because you're not convinced doesn't mean no one else should be. Careful not to fall into the temptation to believe your perspective is objective. Beware the black swan fallacy

At the end of the day, what counts as a "good" or "valid" reason to believe anything is a matter of opinion. I'd say it comes down to usefulness. What counts as "sufficient" evidence is a completely arbitrary line drawn in the sand by people. At some point you just  have to say "even though I could continue to be infinitely skeptical about God, as I could be with any claim, I've seen enough. I'm convinced."

>At the end of the day, what counts as a "good" or "valid" reason to believe anything is a matter of opinion.

No. Objective truth exists.

Drinking battery acid has no good or valid reason. It is objectively bad for humans.

Your opinion and reasoning are irrelevant.

>No. Objective truth exists.

That's a belief inside your subjective mind

How could you ever step outside of your subjective mind to verify that "objective truth" (that which exists "outside" of your mind) actually exists? You could never. You simply have to believe in it

>But just because you personally don't see any convincing reason or evidence for something, doesn't mean there objectively isn't any.

What is the evidence you're referring to?

Of course this is all a matter of opinion, but that doesn't mean we have to throw our hands up and decide the truth is unknowable. This sub is premised on the notion that rational discourse can be used to reach conclusions. No reasonable person would be "infinitely skeptical" of claims supported by evidence without resorting to solipsism.

>What is the evidence you're referring to?

Well, take the appearance of design and fine tuning of the laws of physics as one example

Many people see that as evidence for a creator. If something appears designed, they reason, it probably indicates some designer, right? That's a perfectly reasonable conclusion to draw based on some evidence, in my and many people's opinion. For many people that's where they subjectively draw the line in the sand and say "I've seen enough"

Now, the atheist looks at that and is still not convinced, because he "decides" (not saying he's necessarily "free" to do so) to draw his line a little (maybe a lot) farther back, clings to his skepticism and posits alternative reasons and hypotheses to rationalize away that appearance of design. "Maybe there are infinite alternate universes, and we could only exist in the one that allows for it." For whatever reason he comes up with, he's not quite convinced. He rejects the God explanation in favor of another. Which is fine, but for him to say that his reasons for not being convinced, however rational he may think they are, mean that there's objectively no evidence, is the height of hubris. There clearly is evidence to many people, just none that he personally accepts.

I've seen people like Matt Dilahunty go as far as to say that if God came down to Earth and declared he existed to everyone, he would still not be entirely convinced - after all, maybe it could be aliens? Maybe Matt is just hallucinating it? How do we even know this thing that came down to Earth is in fact the God that it claims to be? To which I say, that's a level of infinite skepticism even more ridiculous than a flat earther. To me it seems clear he's engaging in motivated reasoning, because he doesn't want to believe God exists (for obvious reasons; he's said himself that if God exists he still wouldn't worship him and would hate him,) so he keeps shifting the goalposts every time someone comes up with some reason or evidence that might indicate an unwanted conclusion. It doesn't really seem to me like there's any amount of evidence you could show someone like Matt Dilahunty (and many other atheists in my experience) that would satisfy them. They just cling to their skepticism, which anyone could always do for any claim. The line in the sand just keeps moving back...

>Well, take the appearance of design and fine tuning of the laws of physics as one example

>Many people see that as evidence for a creator. If something appears designed, they reason, it probably indicates some designer, right? That's a perfectly reasonable conclusion to draw based on some evidence, in my and many people's opinion.

"We can see buildings and art have creators, thefore god and the universe!"

I could follow the beginning and end of their projects and document the entire process.

We can't do any of this for the claim that god created all things.
